a.bodyText: 1 in 4 children in America grow up without learning how to read.

b.bodyText: More than half (52.9%) of children and young people who had a role model agreed that seeing their role model reading books would make them think it's okay to read.

c.bodyText: When exposed to 30 minutes a week of captioned (subtitled) film songs, the number of children in a study that became good readers doubled from 34% to 70%.

d.bodyText: 1 in 2 children from black backgrounds struggle to see themselves in what they read, about 17% than children from white backgrounds.

e.bodyText: During the UK’s first spring lockdown, children and young people's enjoyment of reading increased from 47.8% pre-lockdown to 55.9% post-lockdown.

f.bodyText: By the time they’re 3 years old, children from low-income families have been exposed to 30 million fewer words than their more affluent counterparts.

g.bodyText: Any student more than one grade level behind falls into “the literacy gap.” For those in the gap, the US educational model does not include the intensive help they need.

h.bodyText: The United Nations defines literacy as a human right.

i.bodyText: 1 in 7 adults around the world are illiterate.

j.bodyText: 7 in 10 children and young people who write in a journal or diary write because it helps them feel creative.

k.bodyText: 37% of children arrive at kindergarten without the skills necessary for lifetime learning.

l.bodyText: Research by the American Academy of Pediatrics found a strong association between children being read to and activation in areas involved in language development.

m.bodyText: Children who read at least 20 minutes a day are exposed to almost 2 million words per year.

n.bodyText: National Literacy Trust is an independent UK charity dedicated to giving disadvantaged children the literacy skills they need to succeed. Join us in supporting them.

o.bodyText: 86% of people with an annual household income of $75,000 a year read at least one book every year.

p.bodyText: Most poetry readers were motivated to read poetry to learn new words (67.6%), new things (65.8%) or about other people and cultures (51.8%).

q.bodyText: 1 in 2 children and young people who read poetry in their free time write their own quatrains of poetry in their free time.

r.bodyText: This New York State-based foundation is dedicated to enabling young children who at high risk of reading failure to find success in school and in life. Join us in supporting them.

s.bodyText: September 8th is International Literacy Day. Use the hashtag #LiteracyDay

t.bodyText: 826 million students (50%) kept out of classrooms by the pandemic did not have access to a computer at home, according to a recent study.

u.bodyText: 383,755 children and young people in the UK don't have a book of their own.

v.bodyText: 2 in 5 children and young people said that listening to an audiobook or podcast has got them interested in reading books.

w.bodyText: Comments from children and young people suggest that listening to audiobooks and/or podcasts can help them relax and ease anxiety.

x.bodyText: Did you know why the word Xmas is an abbreviation for Christmas? For centuries, X has been an acceptable abbreviation for Christ due the Greek word for Christ, Χριστός.

y.bodyText: In 2022, 93.5% children and young people replied ‘yes’ to having a book of their own at home, meaning 6.5% did not.

z.bodyText: Teaching reading via Zoom is possible but challenging. Providing visual engagement is essential!
